Questions and Answers About Adhesives, Sealants and Cleaning Compounds

geninfo.title: Application of Special Adhesives, Sealants and Cleaning Compounds
geninfo.para: In a continuing effort to keep service personnel informed of the latest service procedures, Navistar has provided a listing of various applications for adhesives, sealants, and cleaning compounds. This listing comes complete with the sizes available for each product and Fleetrite part numbers.

Refer to Figure 1 and Figure 2 for applications of special adhesives, sealants and cleaning components. Only the material with assigned service part numbers approved by Fleetrite are listed. It is important to note that there are different types of material for different applications.

geninfo.title: Questions and Answers About Adhesives, Sealants and Cleaning Compounds

lev1.title: BASIC PRINCIPLES OF ADHESIVES
lev1.para: We have included a helpful information, questions and answers portion of this letter prepared by Loctite Corporation. This information is to assist Service Technicians in the selection of appropriate adhesives and sealants.

para.emph: Q: What can Fleetrite Adhesive/Sealants do for me?

lev1.para: A: Just a few examples. They can:

item.para: Prevent fasteners from loosening - Lock N' Seal
Seal leaky threaded fittings - Pipe Sealant with Teflon
Keep bearings from spinning out - Sleeve N' Bearing Mount
Restore fit between worn bearings, sleeves, gears, pulleys - Sleeve N' Bearing Mount
Seal flanged assemblies - Gasket Eliminator® 515, Ultra Blue TM, Form-A-Gasket®

lev1.para: Q: How do these adhesive/sealants work? ( Figure 3)
A: Applied as a liquid or a paste, they automatically harden into a tough resin between threads or close fitting parts. They lock and seal after assembly.

para.emph: Q: Can I get the parts apart?

lev1.para: A: Yes. Use a little extra elbow grease and ordinary tools on fasteners. Use a bearing puller or a press for bearings or sleeves. Heat at 550°F (288°C) will help loosen parts. Take apart while hot.
Q: Can I re-use the parts? ( Figure 4)
A: Yes. Knock or blow off the loose particles and re-apply the adhesive/sealant. Material can be removed by wire brush if necessary.
Q: How do I clean the parts? ( Figure 5)
A: Clean with Clean N' Cure Primer or Cleaner Parts Solvent, if available. Or use ordinary shop solvent, or wipe off with clean shop towel.
Q: What happens if I apply adhesive/sealant and it doesn't work? ( Figure 6)
A: Three things could have happened.

item.para: Sufficient material was not applied to fill the joint.
Insufficient time was allowed for cure.
Parts were excessively oily, dirty or greasy, which may prevent the adhesive/sealant from curing.

para.emph: Q: What should I do then?

lev1.para: A: Clean all parts thoroughly, using a wire wheel or putty knife and a solvent. When all parts are clean and dry, apply Clean N' Cure Primer. Let it dry, then apply adhesive sealant. Allow sufficient time to cure.
Q: How much temperature will the adhesive/sealant stand? ( Figure 7)
A: -65°F (-54°C) to 300°F (149°C) for both Lock N' Seal products, Pipe Sealant with Teflon, Sleeve N' Bearing Mount and Gasket Eliminator 515.

Q: Will hydraulic oil, motor oil, fuel or water dissolve the adhesive/sealant?
( Figure 8)
A: No. These adhesive/sealants are solvent resistant to all the ordinary liquids and gases.
Q: How do I apply adhesive/sealant? ( Figure 9)

A: Simply apply from bottle nozzle to one part. Apply sufficient amount to fill the gap between parts. Adhesive/sealant will not harden while in contact with air - hardens only in the joint after assembly.

para.emph: Q: What happens if I leave the cap off a bottle or tube?

lev1.para: A: Nothing. It won't harden in the tube or bottle or evaporate.

lev1.title: SHAFT MOUNTING
lev1.para:
Q: Can I use Sleeve N' Bearing Mount to fill the clearance between a bearing and a worn housing or shaft?
( Figure 10)
A: Yes. It will fill a clearance up to .005 inch (.13 mm). Holding power is equal to a press fit.

para.emph: Q: How do I use Sleeve N' Bearing Mount?

lev1.para: A: Spray parts with Clean N' Cure Primer. Apply compound to shaft or bore. Assemble in normal way.
How to use Sleeve N' Bearing Mount ( Figure 11)

item.para: Spray with Clean N' Cure Primer. Let dry 2 or 3 minutes.
Cure two hours at room temperature.
Press fits can be used at once. On slip fits, allow 2 hours for full cure.

lev1.title: PRIMING AND PREPARATION
lev1.para: Q: In general, how fast will adhesive/sealant cure? ( Figure 12)
A: Usually fixtures in 1 hour. Fully cured in 4 hours.

Q: How can I speed up the cure if I have to go right back into service?
( Figure 13)
A: Apply Clean N' Cure Primer on parts before applying sealant. Cuts cure time in half, or apply heat to 300°F (149°C); this will cure material in 15 minutes.

lev1.title: PIPE SEALING
lev1.para:
Q: We use Teflon tape to seal threaded fittings. Why should I use Pipe Sealant with Teflon?
( Figure 14 and Figure 15)

A: Teflon tape can shred and get into systems which may block orifices and valves. Pipe Sealant with Teflon is easier to apply, locks and seals fittings at any angle. Won't vibrate loose. Forms a solid seal. Withstands high pressures.

lev1.title: GASKETING
lev1.para: Q: How does Gasket Eliminator 515 work? ( Figure 16)

A: Gasket Eliminator forms the gasket in place. When confined between the assembled flanges, the gel-like material automatically converts into a tough sealing gasket. It resists heat to 300°F (177°C). Also resists water, oil and solvents. One tube makes many sizes and shapes of gaskets.
Q: How do I apply Gasket Eliminator 515? ( Figure 17)

A: Apply directly from the nozzle applicator on the tube. No mixing. No heat cure. For most joints, apply a 1/16 inch (1.59 mm) diameter bead around the bolt holes and between the bolt holes centered on the flanges. Material does not cure until flanges are mated together. Be sure that the material will be in contact with both flanges when parts are assembled.

para.emph: Q: Can I get the flanges apart?

lev1.para: A: Yes. Tap on flanges to loosen.
Q: How do I clean off the cured material? ( Figure 18 and Figure 19)

A: For most flanged joints, it is not necessary to remove the cured material. Wipe off surface with a clean shop towel and apply a new bead. If it is a very critical dimension joint, remove all residue by applying Gasket Remover or by scraping with a putty knife or wire wheel. Then clean up with Clean N' Cure Primer before re-assembly.
Q: Where can I use Gasket Eliminator 515? ( Figure 20)
A: Rigid flanges such as axle shaft flanges, flywheel housing and other rigid covers, plates. Use only where the change in joint thickness will not affect internal clearances.

para.emph: Q: Where do I use Make-a-Gasket #2?

lev1.para: A: Use to dress cut paper and cork gaskets such as on oil pans, transmissions and timing covers. Use also to seal hose connections.
Q: Where do I use Ultra Blue RTV Silicone Gasket? ( Figure 21)

A: A formed-in-place gasketing material three times more oil resistant than other RTV silicones; use on valve covers, oil pans or other applications requiring a flexible gasket. For Navistar applications, the non-corrosive to electrical contacts components, such as two speed shift motor, are most important.
Q: What is good use for Superflex™ Clear RTV Silicone? ( Figure 22)

A: Use where cosmetic appearance is important. Dries clear and flexible. Maximum temperature 400°F (204°C). Use for caulking of windshields, windshield frames, lights and weatherstripping. Adheres to glass, metal, wood and rubber.

para.emph: Q: Where do I use Form-a-Gasket Black RTV Silicone?

lev1.para: A: Use on flexible flanges to make form-in-place gaskets, where oil resistance is required. Or use for same application as Superflex Clear RTV when black color is desired.
